title: Bilateral CPA Lesions (Neurofibromatosis)
chief_complaint: I have a high-pitched ringing in both ears, but it pulses in my left ear. Over the last six months, I've lost hearing in my right ear and feel slightly off-balance.

problem_summary.onset: Tinnitus began 1 year ago; hearing loss began 6 months ago.
problem_summary.course: Progressive hearing loss on the right side.
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral tinnitus (pulsatile left), Right hearing loss.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Slight imbalance, intolerance to motion. History of vertigo with vomiting 10 years prior (resolved).

history.present_illness: 50-year-old woman complaining of bilateral high-pitched tinnitus of 1-year duration (pulsatile in the left ear). 6-month history of progressive right-sided hearing loss, slight imbalance, and intolerance to motion.
history.otologic_history: Ten years previously experienced two episodes of vertigo with vomiting which resolved spontaneously without recurrence.
history.medical_psych_history: Diagnosed with neurofibromatosis at age 50 (during this evaluation process).
history.patient_goals: Evaluation of hearing loss and tinnitus.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Left ear: Normal hearing sensitivity. Right ear: Moderate to severe high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss.

numeric_results.RE_thresholds: 250-500Hz ~30 dB HL, 1000Hz ~15 dB HL, sloping to ~50 dB HL at 2000Hz and ~65 dB HL at 8000Hz

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Excellent speech recognition scores bilaterally despite the right-sided loss.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.key_findings: Abnormal bilaterally. Left ear: Extended absolute latency for wave V and abnormal III-V/I-V intervals (consistent with brainstem lesion). Right ear: Extended I-V interval and missing Wave III (consistent with acoustic nerve or brainstem lesion).

tests.name: MRI
tests.key_findings: Mass lesions of the Cerebellopontine Angle (CPA) on both sides. Right side: Probable acoustic tumor with lateral extension into the Internal Auditory Meatus (IAM). Left side: Probable meningioma.

overall_audiologic_summary: This 50-year-old female presented with bilateral tinnitus and progressive right-sided hearing loss. Audiometry revealed normal hearing in the left ear and a high-frequency sensorineural loss in the right ear, though speech recognition remained excellent bilaterally. ABR was abnormal bilaterally; the right ear showed signs of retrocochlear pathology (extended I-V, missing III), while the left ear showed signs consistent with brainstem compression (extended III-V). MRI confirmed bilateral CPA lesions: a probable acoustic tumor on the right extending into the IAM (explaining the cochlear/nerve findings) and a meningioma on the left (compressing the brainstem). The patient was subsequently diagnosed with Neurofibromatosis.
counseling_points: Discuss MRI findings indicating bilateral CPA masses.
Explain the diagnosis of Neurofibromatosis (unusually late diagnosis at age 50).
Correlate the right-sided hearing loss with the tumor's presence in the Internal Auditory Meatus.
Explain that the left-sided ABR abnormalities are likely due to brainstem compression by the meningioma.
Surgical consultation is required (patient had not yet gone to surgery at time of report).
notes_for_actor: Portray a patient who is concerned about the progressive nature of the hearing loss and the constant ringing.
You have a history of vertigo 10 years ago, but currently, you only feel 'slight imbalance' and motion intolerance, not full spinning vertigo.
The tinnitus in the left ear is pulsatile (like a heartbeat), which is distinct from the high-pitched ringing.
